citations.narrative:
***USDA observed five large breed dogs in a pen in the exhibit area. There are no records for review as are required in
Subpart G, Section 2.75 of the Regulations. In addition, the dogs are not currently listed on the animal inventory. The
dogs shall be removed from exhibition or added to the inventory and records shall be developed and maintained fully
disclosing all information as required in this section.
Correct by October 31, 2023.

***USDA observed several customers approaching enclosures containing cattle, sheep, llama, Patagonian cavy, rabbits,
camels and chickens with no attendants present or monitoring the interaction. The customers were able to feed and pet
the animals. Throughout the inspection USDA observed two attendants present managing the pony rides, and two at the
ticket office, but there were none out in the park observing the general public's interaction with the animals. The absence
of barriers as well as the lack of oversight by an attendant increases the risk of harm to the animal and to the public.
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals
and the public.
Correct by October 31, 2023.

***The rabbits are group housed on the ground in the barn. There is a layer of wood shavings covering the ground with an
excess amount of excreta dispersed throughout. The shavings do not appear to have been changed recently or at an
appropriate frequency to provide adequate cleaning for the number of rabbits housed in the enclosure. Excess
accumulations of excreta increases the risk of disease hazards which may lead to illness.
The enclosure shall be cleaned at a frequency that will allow the rabbits to remain free from contamination and protect
them from the presence of disease hazard.
Correct by October 28, 2023

***The fence around the large pig enclosure is in disrepair. There are large gaps over and around the culvert large
enough to allow the pigs to get out or easily allow, humans and other animals access into the enclosure. There are other
areas along the fence where the dirt has eroded or the wooden cross board is no longer present leaving gaps as large as
12 inches or more between the fence and the dirt.
There is a fence board laying on the ground in the enclosure housing 3 sheep with 3 screws with sharp tips pointing out of
the end of the boards. The sheep were observed walking around and over the boards. These screws may cause injuries
such as puncture wounds and cuts. The board was removed prior to end of inspection.
The fences shall be repaired and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Office Attendant onsite and later with the Owner by phone.
